newsitem.title: INDIA: Sonia Gandhi, Indian dynasty's standard-bearer.
newsitem.headline: Sonia Gandhi, Indian dynasty's standard-bearer.

text.p: Sonia Gandhi, whose decision to join her late husband's Congress party was announced on Thursday, is India's favourite enigma.

The Italian-born widow of former prime minister Rajiv Gandhi, whose family members have ruled India for 38 of its 50 years since independence from Britain, has enrolled as a party member, Congress president Sitaram Kesri said.
For Indians it was a move fraught with significance.
Often since 1991, when a Sri Lankan Tamil suicide bomber killed Rajiv Gandhi in an election rally, Sonia had spurned calls to inherit her husband's political mantle.
But her presence has been noticed during visits by world leaders who are as apt to call on her as on opposition leaders.

Congress, weakened by feuds and corruption scandals, has sought a role for her since the elegant, now naturalised Indian citizen, shrouded in a white sari of Hindu mourning, brought her mangled husband's corpse to lie in state.
Sonia, aged 50, has also addressed gatherings organised by the Rajiv Gandhi Foundation, a non-profit think tank and social organisation formed in her husband's memory.

Aside from the much-talked-about wedding of her daughter, Priyanka, to a New Delhi businessman in February, Sonia has been the subject of magazine cover stories, lurid headlines and a favourite topic of armchair political experts.
In the only instance that smacked of politics, Sonia Gandhi complained about the slow progress of an inquiry into her husband's murder during a public meeting two years ago.
Her apparent target was then prime minister P.V. Narasimha Rao, whose authority was gradually undermined by Congress rebels close to Sonia Gandhi.

Sonia Gandhi was named in a survey in April, 1996 as the most popular choice for prime minister after then Congress chief Narasimha Rao and Atal Bihari Vajapyee, leader of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party.
Rao quit the prime ministership one month later after general elections, and Vajpayee held the post for only 12 days before giving way to H.D. Deve Gowda's centre-left coalition.
Sonia's mystique derives from the dynasty which is tightly associated with India's freedom fight against the British and its struggle as an independent nation since 1947.

On May 21, 1991, the woman suicide bomber robbed Sonia of the man she had called her "greatest security" when he entered the volatile politics of the world's most populous democracy after the assassination of his mother, Indira Gandhi, in 1984.
In the early 1990s, Indians speculated she would enter politics herself with a flourish, draw on Rajiv's popularity and become India's first non-native-born prime minister.
Others said Rajiv Gandhi's death had ended the dynasty.
A furore over alleged illegal payments in an arms case had contributed to Rajiv Gandhi's defeat in 1989. The family has denied any involvement in one of India's longest-running scandals.
By mid-1996, with Congress fractured and ridden with corruption scandals, there was a growing conviction she would remain a powerful party figure behind the scenes.
News on Thursday that she had decided to join the political fray could mark her coming out.
Born on December 9, 1946, into the family of a middle-class Turin businessman, she was thrust into the political limelight by three deaths in just over a decade.
When the former convent schoolgirl married Rajiv Gandhi in 1968 after a romance in Britain's university town of Cambridge, her husband was an unassuming pilot for Indian Airlines.
But he was also the scion of India's first family, the son and grandson of prime ministers Indira Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru.
Neither of Sonia and Rajiv's two children, Rahul, 26, or Priyanka, 24, has expressed a desire to enter politics.
